intro: Razoumofskya tsugensis, commonly known as the Japanese sedge, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to East Asia. It belongs to the family Cyperaceae, which includes sedges and related plants. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as forests and wetlands. Its slender stems are often clustered, and it produces small, inconspicuous flowers in clusters. The leaves are linear and grass-like, contributing to its resemblance to other sedges in the family.
